msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Exodus 32
ab.l:
And the people saw
that Moses was delaying to come down from the mountain, and the people were gathered
to Aaron, and said to him, ‘Get up. Make us
leaders who shall go before us, because this Moses, the
prophet, that brought us out from the land of Egypt, we do not know what has become
of him.’

And Aaron said to them, ‘Break off
the golden earrings which are in the ears of your wives of your sons,
and of your daughters, and bring |them| to me.’

And
all the people broke off the golden earrings which were in their ears,
and brought |them| to Aaron.

And
he took them from their hand, and tied them in a pouch and
he made it a molten calf. And they said, ‘These are your leaders,
oh Israel, who brought you out from the land of Egypt.’

And Aaron saw that this was what happened,
and he built an altar before it to delay somewhat the |events|. And Aaron called,
and he said, ‘A feast to the Lord at daybreak.’

And they rose up early after daybreak and offered burnt offerings and brought
peace offerings. And the people sat down to eat and to drink,
and rose up to play.

And the Lord said to Moses,
‘Go, go down, because your people whom you brought out from the land of Egypt have destroyed your path.

They have went quickly out of the way which I commanded them.
They have made for themselves a molten calf, and they have worshiped it, and they have
sacrificed to it, and they said, “These are your leaders,
oh Israel, who have brought you from the land of Egypt.”’

And
the Lord said to Moses, ‘I have seen this people,
and, lo, it is a stiff-necked people.

And now
let me alone, and my anger shall kindle against them, and let me destroy and consume them, and I will make you into a great
kingdom.’

And Moses besought the directions of the Lord
his God, and said, ‘Oh Lord, why does your anger kindle against your people
whom you have brought out from the land of Egypt with great power and with a mighty hand?

Why should the Egyptians speak, saying, “He brought them out with evil |intent|,
to kill them in the mountains and to consume
them from the face of the earth?” Turn back from your furious anger,
and spare your people this evil.

Remember the covenant of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Israel, your servants,
to whom you swore by your own self, and said to them, saying,
“I will multiply your offspring like the stars of the skies,
and I will give to your offspring all this land that I have spoken of,
and they shall inherit it forever.”’

And
the Lord spared his people the evil which he had spoken, to do
to his own people.

And Moses turned and went down
from the mountain, and the two tablets of the law were in his hand,
tablets written on both their sides, on this side and on this side
they were written.

And the tablets were the work of God,
and the writing was the writing of God, engraved on the tablets.

And when Joshua heard the
noise of the shouting people, he said to Moses,
‘There is a noise of war in the camp.’

And he said, ‘It is not
the voice of strong shouting, and it is not the voice of weak shouting:
I hear the sound of a song.’

And it was, as soon as he
came near to the camp, that he saw the calf and the dancing:
and Moses’ anger kindled, and he cast the tablets out of his hands
and broke them at the foot of the mountain.

And he took the calf which they had made, and burned it in the fire,
and ground it to fine |powder|, and scattered
it on the water, and he made the children of Israel drink of it.

And Moses said to Aaron, ‘What did
this people do to you, that you have brought a great sin on it?’

And Aaron said, ‘Let not the anger of my lord kindle:
you know the people, that it is bad.
And

they said to me, “Make us leaders who shall go
before us, because this Moses, the prophet, who brought us out from the land of Egypt:
we do not know what has become of him.”

And I said to them,
“Who has any gold?” They broke it off and they gave it to me, and I cast
it into the fire, and this calf came out.’

And
Moses saw that the people went wrong, because
Aaron had corrupted them — to shame for their adversaries.

And Moses stood in the gate of the camp, and said, ‘Who
is the Lord’s? He shall come to me.’ And all the sons of Levi were gathered to him.

And he said to them, ‘Thus said the Lord,
God of Israel, “Set, each man, his sword on his thigh,
go to and fro from gate to gate in the camp, and kill
each man his brother, and each man his friend, and each man
his nearest.”’

And the sons of Levi did according to the word
of Moses, and three thousand men fell of the people in that day.

And Moses said, ‘Fill your hands
today to serve the Lord — because each man killed
his son and his brother — and to put a blessing on you
today.’

And it was after daybreak, and Moses said to the
people, ‘You have sinned against the Lord a great sin. And now
I will go to the Lord, and I shall ask for atonement for your sin.’

And Moses returned to the Lord, and said, ‘I beg You,
the people have sinned a great sin, and they have made them
idols of gold.

And now, if you will forgive their sin
— good. But if you still will not forgive, blot me out now
from your book that you have written.’

And the Lord said to Moses,
‘The one who has sinned against me, I will blot him out from my book.’

And now, go. Lead the people
to the place of which I have spoken to you. Lo, my angel shall go before you.
And, in the day when I remember: and I will remember what sins they have,
and I will punish them for this sin of theirs.’

And
the Lord made the people sick, because they had made
the calf, which Aaron had made.
